name: Greek Mythology
description: The Judgment of Paris is one of Greek mythology's most consequential tales - a beauty contest among three goddesses that ignited the Trojan War. When Paris, prince of Troy, was forced to judge who was fairest among Hera, Athena, and Aphrodite, his choice set in motion a decade-long war that destroyed civilizations and birthed epic poetry.

historicalContext.setting: Mount Ida, where Paris shepherded flocks after being exposed as infant
historicalContext.trigger: Wedding of Peleus and Thetis (parents of Achilles) - all gods invited except Eris (Discord)
historicalContext.catalyst: Eris threw golden apple inscribed 'To the Fairest' among goddesses
historicalContext.timeframe: Events leading to Trojan War (mythological Bronze Age)

narrativeStructure.setup: Eris excluded from wedding, throws apple of discord
narrativeStructure.conflict: Three goddesses (Hera, Athena, Aphrodite) each claim the apple
narrativeStructure.complication: Zeus refuses to judge, appoints mortal Paris

bribes.hera: Power and kingship over all of Europe and Asia
bribes.athena: Wisdom, skill in warfare, victory in all battles
bribes.aphrodite: Love of the most beautiful woman in the world (Helen)

narrativeStructure.climax: Paris awards apple to Aphrodite, choosing love over power/wisdom
narrativeStructure.consequence: Paris abducts/elopes with Helen, sparking Trojan War

significance.choiceOfValues: Represents eternal dilemma of choosing among power, wisdom, and love
significance.fatalShortsi ghtedness: Paris chooses immediate gratification over long-term consequences
significance.divineVanity: Goddesses' willingness to bribe mortal reveals divine pettiness
significance.prophecyFulfilled: Paris's mother dreamed of torch destroying Troy - his choice fulfills prophecy
significance.moralCaughtInDivinePolitics: Mortal thrust into cosmic disputes beyond comprehension

participants: Aphrodite - Winner of the judgment
Hera - Queen of the gods, scorned
Athena - Goddess of wisdom, rejected
Zeus - Refused to judge
Hermes - Messenger to Paris
relatedConcepts: Hera - Queen of the gods, scorned
Achilles - Son of Thetis and Peleus
primarySources: Cypria (lost epic) - Earliest detailed account, 7th century BCE
Homer's Iliad - Allusions to judgment, 8th century BCE
Euripides' plays - Iphigenia at Aulis, Helen
Lucian's Dialogues of the Gods - Satirical version, 2nd century CE

artisticLegacy.ancientArt: Frequently depicted on Greek vases - three goddesses before seated Paris
artisticLegacy.renaissance: Immensely popular allowing artists to paint three female nudes (Cranach, Rubens, Watteau, Boucher)
artisticLegacy.modernRetellings: Contemporary authors reimagine from various perspectives (Madeline Miller, Margaret Atwood, Pat Barker)

name: Japanese Mythology
description: The myth of Amaterasu hiding in the Heavenly Rock Cave is one of the most celebrated stories in Japanese mythology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE). When Amaterasu, the sun goddess, sealed herself in a cave to escape her brother Susanoo's violent rampage, the world plunged into eternal darkness. The myth explains the origins of sacred Shinto rituals, especially kagura dance, and illustrates how cleverness, cooperation, and sacred celebration can overcome even cosmic calamity.

historicalContext.setting: Takamagahara (High Plain of Heaven) and Ama-no-Iwato (Heavenly Rock Cave)
historicalContext.triggeringEvent: Susanoo's violent rampage destroying rice fields, polluting sacred spaces
historicalContext.climacticViolation: Susanoo hurled flayed horse through roof during sacred weaving, killing a maiden
historicalContext.sources: Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE)

narrativeStructure.provocation: Susanoo's escalating crimes - destroyed rice paddies, polluted harvest hall, killed weaving maiden
narrativeStructure.withdrawal: Amaterasu, horrified and grieving, seals herself in cave with boulder
narrativeStructure.consequence: Eternal darkness covers both heaven and earth, evil spirits multiply
narrativeStructure.divineCouncil: Eight million kami gather at Heavenly River led by Omoikane (Wisdom God)
narrativeStructure.ritualSolution: Sacred ceremony to lure Amaterasu out through curiosity and celebration
narrativeStructure.resolution: Amaterasu emerges, light returns, Susanoo is punished and exiled

ritualElements.sacredRooster: Nagaki-no-tori roosters crow to announce dawn in darkness
ritualElements.sacredMirror: Yata-no-Kagami crafted to reflect Amaterasu's light
ritualElements.sakakiTree: Sacred tree hung with mirrors, jewels, and offerings
ritualElements.amenoUzume: Goddess performs ecstatic dance that makes gods laugh
ritualElements.curiosity: Amaterasu emerges to see what causes divine laughter

significance.ritualOrigins: Explains origin of kagura (sacred Shinto dance)
significance.imperialRegalia: Three Sacred Treasures of Japan originate in this myth (mirror, jewel, sword)
significance.solarMythology: Eclipse myth - sun's disappearance and return
significance.conflictResolution: Cooperation, cleverness, and celebration overcome violence and chaos
significance.shintoValues: Community action, ritual purity, divine accessibility through proper ceremony

participants: Amaterasu - Sun goddess who hides
Susanoo - Storm god whose violence triggers crisis
Ame-no-Uzume - Goddess whose dance lures Amaterasu out
Omoikane - Wisdom god who devises the plan
Tajikara-wo - Strong deity who pulls boulder away

name: Sumerian/Babylonian Mythology
description: The Epic of Gilgamesh is the oldest known work of epic literature, originating in ancient Mesopotamia around 2100 BCE. It tells the story of Gilgamesh, the mighty king of Uruk, and his quest for immortality following the death of his beloved companion Enkidu. The epic explores timeless themes of friendship, mortality, legacy, and the limits of human ambition, establishing narrative patterns that would echo through world literature for millennia.

historicalContext.origin: Sumerian poems about Gilgamesh (c. 2100 BCE) compiled into Akkadian epic (c. 1800-1600 BCE)
historicalContext.historicalKing: Gilgamesh may have been actual king of Uruk (c. 2700 BCE)
historicalContext.rediscovery: Tablets discovered in Nineveh library of Ashurbanipal (1849-1854)
historicalContext.culturalImpact: Influenced Biblical flood narrative and hero's journey archetype

narrativeStructure.act1_tyrant: Gilgamesh oppresses Uruk - gods create Enkidu as rival/equal
narrativeStructure.act2_friendship: Epic battle transforms into deep friendship - first great literary friendship
narrativeStructure.act3_glory: Quest to Cedar Forest, slaying Humbaba, cutting sacred trees
narrativeStructure.act4_hubris: Rejecting Ishtar, slaying Bull of Heaven, angering gods
narrativeStructure.act5_loss: Enkidu dies as punishment - Gilgamesh confronts mortality
narrativeStructure.act6_quest: Journey to Utnapishtim seeking immortality secret
narrativeStructure.act7_failure: Fails tests, loses plant of immortality, returns to Uruk
narrativeStructure.resolution: Acceptance of mortality, finding meaning in legacy and accomplishment

majorThemes.friendship: Transformative power of deep companionship - violence to love
majorThemes.mortality: Inescapable human condition - even heroes must die
majorThemes.ambitionLimits: Some quests (immortality) are beyond human reach
majorThemes.civilization: Enkidu's transformation from wild man to civilized human
majorThemes.grief: Overwhelming power of loss to transform personality and priorities

participants: Gilgamesh - The hero king of Uruk
Enkidu - Wild man companion
Ishtar/Inanna - Goddess of love and war
Enlil - Lord of wind and storm
Ea/Enki - God of wisdom
Shamash - Sun god who aids heroes
Utnapishtim - Immortal flood survivor
Humbaba - Guardian of Cedar Forest
relatedConcepts: The Odyssey - Later Greek epic parallel
significance: Explores universal themes still resonant today

name: Sumerian Mythology
description: The Descent of Inanna is one of the oldest recorded myths in human history, preserved on cuneiform tablets from ancient Sumer. The goddess Inanna, Queen of Heaven and Earth, descends to the underworld realm of Kur to visit her sister Ereshkigal, Queen of the Dead. At each of seven gates, she is stripped of her divine powers and regalia, arriving naked and powerless before the throne of death itself.

historicalContext.age: c. 1900-1600 BCE (tablets) - oral tradition much older
historicalContext.culturalContext: Central to Mesopotamian understandings of death, fertility, seasonal cycles

narrativeStructure.preparation: Inanna adorns herself with seven me (divine powers) as garments/jewelry
narrativeStructure.precaution: Instructs minister Ninshubur to seek help if she doesn't return
narrativeStructure.descent: Arrives at outer gate, demands entry to underworld
narrativeStructure.stripping: At each of seven gates, one divine power removed
narrativeStructure.judgment: Naked and powerless, judged by seven Anunnaki, turned to corpse, hung on hook
narrativeStructure.rescue: After three days, Enki creates mourning creatures who empathize with Ereshkigal
narrativeStructure.revival: Sprinkled with food and water of life, Inanna rises
narrativeStructure.substitute: Must provide substitute - condemns husband Dumuzi for not mourning
narrativeStructure.resolution: Dumuzi spends half year in underworld, sister Geshtinanna the other half

sevenGates.gate2: Measuring rod and line taken - authority over civilization lost
sevenGates.gate3: Lapis lazuli beads removed - adornment gone
sevenGates.gate4: Breastplate 'Come, man, come!' stripped - seductive power lost
sevenGates.gate5: Gold ring taken - royal status removed
sevenGates.gate6: Lapis lazuli necklace removed - further disempowerment
sevenGates.gate7: Royal robe stripped off - final vestige of divinity gone
sevenGates.gatekeeperResponse: Be satisfied, Inanna, the ways of the underworld are perfect. They may not be questioned.

significance.deathRitual: Template for understanding death as stripping away all earthly powers and identities
significance.seasonalCycle: Dumuzi's alternation explains agricultural seasons - life and death cycles
significance.initiationMyth: Death and rebirth as transformative spiritual journey
significance.shadowIntegration: Confronting one's dark sister (Ereshkigal) as psychological necessity
significance.powerSurrender: True descent requires total vulnerability - all defenses removed

participants: Inanna - Queen of Heaven and Earth
Ereshkigal - Queen of the Underworld
Enki - God of Wisdom and Water
Dumuzi - Inanna's husband, condemned as substitute
Ninshubur - Inanna's loyal minister
Geshtinanna - Dumuzi's sister who shares his fate
relatedConcepts: The Underworld (Kur) - Realm of the dead
Orpheus and Eurydice - Failed rescue from underworld
Izanagi's Journey to Yomi - Japanese parallel
primarySources: Diane Wolkstein & Samuel Noah Kramer: 'Inanna, Queen of Heaven and Earth' (1983)
